review.title: Discovery Radiomics via Evolutionary Deep Radiomic Sequencer Discovery for Pathologically-Proven Lung Cancer Detection
review.abstract: While lung cancer is the second most diagnosed form of cancer in men and women, a sufficiently early diagnosis can be pivotal in patient survival rates. Imaging-based, or radiomics-driven, detection methods have been developed to aid diagnosticians, but largely rely on hand-crafted features which may not fully encapsulate the differences between cancerous and healthy tissue. Recently, the concept of discovery radiomics was introduced, where custom abstract features are discovered from readily available imaging data. We propose a novel evolutionary deep radiomic sequencer discovery approach based on evolutionary deep intelligence. Motivated by patient privacy concerns and the idea of operational artificial intelligence, the evolutionary deep radiomic sequencer discovery approach organically evolves increasingly more efficient deep radiomic sequencers that produce significantly more compact yet similarly descriptive radiomic sequences over multiple generations. As a result, this framework improves operational efficiency and enables diagnosis to be run locally at the radiologist's computer while maintaining detection accuracy. We evaluated the evolved deep radiomic sequencer (EDRS) discovered via the proposed evolutionary deep radiomic sequencer discovery framework against state-of-the-art radiomics-driven and discovery radiomics methods using clinical lung CT data with pathologically-proven diagnostic data. The evolved deep radiomic sequencer shows state-of-the-art diagnostic accuracy (88.78%) relative to previous radiomics approaches.

metadata.title: Discovery Radiomics via Evolutionary Deep Radiomic Sequencer Discovery for Pathologically-Proven Lung Cancer Detection

sections.heading: II. METHODS
sections.text: In this section, we will first discuss the concepts behind discovery radiomics and evolutionary depth intelligence, and then present the proposed evolutionary depth sequencer discovery approach in detail.

sections.heading: A. Discovery Radiomics
sections.text: The idea behind discovery radiomics can be described as follows (see Figure 1): Based on earlier radiological data and corresponding pathologically verified radiological tissue annotations from a medical imaging data repository, the discovery process learns a radio sequencer that can extract highly customized radiographic features (which we will call radiographic sequences) tailored to characterize unique tissue phenotypes that distinguish cancer tissues from healthy tissues.The discovered radiographic sequencer can be applied to new patient data to extract the corresponding radiographic sequence for cancer screening and diagnostic tissues.As previously discussed, one of the most important limitations of the deep radiographic sequencer proposed to date for the purpose of lung cancer detection is that both diagnostically powerful and computationally expensive and memory-intensive sequence data would require additional clinical efficiencies that would make it more difficult to deploy in the clinical cloud and allow for the transfer of high-performance clinical information19.

sections.heading: B. Evolutionary Deep Intelligence
sections.text: Before describing the proposed evolutionary deep-sequencer-deep-intelligence approach, it is first important to discuss the idea behind the evolutionary deep-intelligence. Initially introduced by Shafiee et al. [18], the general idea is to synthesize progressively more efficient deep-neural networks over several generations. Deep-neural networks evolution is modelled in a probabilistic manner, encoding the architectural features of ancestor networks through probabilistic DNA. Probabilistic DNA is used to mimic biological heritability, and new progeny networks are stochastically synthesized on the basis of this probabilistic model. To conclude the evolutionary cycle, environmental factors are applied to the model to mimic random mutations and natural selection. In each generation, the progeny network (which is more efficient than its parent) is then trained to enhance its modeling abilities and to maximize its modeling ability.

sections.heading: C. Evolutionary Deep Radiomic Sequencer Discovery
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before an agreement is reached.

sections.heading: III. RESULTS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: A. Experimental Setup
sections.text: The proposed in-depth radioeconomic sequencers were developed using the pathologically detected subset of the LIDC-IDRI [21], [22] datasets and compared with current methods. In this section, the configuration of datasets containing the underlying radiographic sequencers and the competing methods is explained. 1) Lung Dataset: In this study, we used the subset of LIDC-IDRI [21] datasets containing corresponding pathology-detected diagnostic data. CT images were executed using a wide range of scanner models from different manufacturing countries applying the following peak energies: 120kV (n = 818), 130kV = 135kV (n = 69), and 140kV (n = 100).

sections.heading: B. Experimental Results
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we proposed a new evolutionary Deep Radiomic Sequencer Discovery Framework to find more efficient but more powerful Radiomic Sequencers for classifying lung cancer. An evolutionary Deep Intelligence approach is integrated into the Discovery Radiomics Framework to develop the underlying deep neural network architecture of the Deep Radiomic Sequencer over several generations and to discover a more efficient and generalized Deep Radiomic Sequencer. The ultimate goal is to synthesize a new Deep Neural Network as the underlying Radiomic Sequencer with a lower number of parameters that generate more accurate radiographic sequencers that can better detect the differences between healthy and cancerous lung tissue. Results show that by developing and discovering more efficient Radiomic Sequencers, diagnostic accuracy can be developed despite the limited number of training data sequencers can better capture the differences between healthy and cancerous lung tissue.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: This research was supported by the Ontario Institute of Cancer Research (OICR), Canada Research Chairs programs, Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC), and the Ministry of Research and Innovation of Ontario. Authors also thank Nvidia for the GPU hardware used in this study as part of the Nvidia Hardware Grant Program.

referenceMentions.context: In 2016, lung cancer accounted for an estimated 158,080 deaths (approximately 27% of cancer deaths) and 224,390 new cases in Americans [1].
Similarly, lung cancer accounted for an estimated 20,800 deaths (approximately 26% of cancer deaths) and 28,400 new cases in Canadians [2].
Referring to the extraction and analysis of large amounts of quantitative features from medical imaging data, radiomics [3]
The prognostic potential of radiomics has previously been demonstrated in studies on lung and head-and-neck cancer patients [4], [5].
The prognostic potential of radiomics has previously been demonstrated in studies on lung and head-and-neck cancer patients [4], [5].

[4] introduced a comprehensive study spanning over 1000 patients across seven datasets to demonstrate the application of radiomics towards differentiating between tumour phenotypes, indicating clinical and prognostic implications.
In addition, radiomics has shown promise in combination with multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging for breast cancer detection [6] and prostate cancer detection [7].
In addition, radiomics has shown promise in combination with multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging for breast cancer detection [6] and prostate cancer detection [7].

[9] generated wavelet-based radiomic sequences and demonstrated the effectiveness of wavelet-based features using a subset of images from the early lung cancer action project (ELCAP) and lung image database consortium (LIDC) datasets.
[10] proposed multi-scale convolutional neural networks (MCNN), a hierarchical framework for extracting discriminative features from lung nodules.

[16] leveraged deep radiomic sequencers built upon a deep convolutional neural network architecture.

Using the concept of evolutionary deep intelligence [18], [19] to mimic biological evolution mechanisms, the proposed evolutionary deep sequencer discovery process discovers progressively more efficient yet diagnostically powerful deep radiomic sequencers over multiple generations.

’s deep autoencoding radiomic sequencer (DARS) [12] uses a five layer de-noising autoencoder trained by L-BFGS with 30 iterations and a batch size of 400, as suggested by past work [24]; a 200 dimension feature vector is extracted from the fourth layer and paired with a binary decision tree classifier.

’s deep autoencoding radiomic sequencer (DARS) [12] uses a five layer de-noising autoencoder trained by L-BFGS with 30 iterations and a batch size of 400, as suggested by past work [24]; a 200 dimension feature vector is extracted from the fourth layer and paired with a binary decision tree classifier.
’s proposed convolutional neural network multiple instance learning (CNN-MIL) [13] is composed of three concatenated convolutional layers, each with 64 convolutional kernels of size 3×3.
’s StochasticNet radiomic sequencer (SNRS) [15] is constructed using three stochastically-formed convolutional layers of 32, 32, and 64 receptive fields, respectively.
’s discovered radiomic sequencer (DRS) [16] comprises of three convolutional sequencing layers of 20, 50, and 500 receptive fields, respectively, each of size 3× 3.
It is worth noting that in lung cancer classification, improving the specificity is challenging [25] and increasing the specificity while maintaining a reasonable sensitivity is highly desirable.

metadata.abstractText: While lung cancer is the second most diagnosed form of cancer in men and women, a sufficiently early diagnosis can be pivotal in patient survival rates. Imaging-based, or radiomics-driven, detection methods have been developed to aid diagnosticians, but largely rely on hand-crafted features which may not fully encapsulate the differences between cancerous and healthy tissue. Recently, the concept of discovery radiomics was introduced, where custom abstract features are discovered from readily available imaging data. We propose a novel evolutionary deep radiomic sequencer discovery approach based on evolutionary deep intelligence. Motivated by patient privacy concerns and the idea of operational artificial intelligence, the evolutionary deep radiomic sequencer discovery approach organically evolves increasingly more efficient deep radiomic sequencers that produce significantly more compact yet similarly descriptive radiomic sequences over multiple generations. As a result, this framework improves operational efficiency and enables diagnosis to be run locally at the radiologist’s computer while maintaining detection accuracy. We evaluated the evolved deep radiomic sequencer (EDRS) discovered via the proposed evolutionary deep radiomic sequencer discovery framework against state-of-the-art radiomics-driven and discovery radiomics methods using clinical lung CT data with pathologically-proven diagnostic data. The evolved deep radiomic sequencer shows state-of-the-art diagnostic accuracy (88.78%) relative to previous radiomics approaches.
